{include "default_salutation"} –

With the May 17 election, voters in several counties will have the opportunity to vote for their county's District Attorney (DA) because DAs are elected officials.

DAs are the most powerful people in Oregon's criminal legal system. They are the top prosecutor in each county. Many of them also actively lobby against smart justice reforms through the Oregon District Attorneys Association. But most Oregon voters don't know who their county DA is and choose not to vote in DA elections.

Visit our website to watch short and informative videos on the role of DAs and the immense power they hold. {link}

As you vote, please keep in mind that:

  • We need DAs who are committed to creating safer communities and not squandering our state's limited resources. Relying on punishment and prison to address our community's hardships diverts billions of dollars into government responses that do not actually solve public problems.
  • We need DAs who are committed to the prevention, treatment, and a focus on addressing the root causes of crime.
  • We need DAs who are committed to holding youth accountable in ways that keep them out of the adult system and are offered an opportunity to rebuild their lives instead of returning to prison.
  • We need DAs who are committed to racial justice.
  • We need DAs who are committed to standing up for reproductive justice and will fight against sex and gender violence for all communities, not just privileged communities.

Please learn more about your county's District Attorney race and vote for the candidate most aligned with civil liberties and civil rights. For more information and excellent short videos.

The ACLU of Oregon (c4 organization) and ACLU Foundation of Oregon (c3 organization) do not endorse specific parties or candidates for office. We may participate in activities related to voter and public education about candidates and issues.

In solidarity,
